column4: i've just started getting an error on startup saying that my $HOME/.dmrc file is being ignored, and that i should make sure that i own it and set the permissions to 644.
i checked the permissions and owner and everything is as it should be.
any suggestions?
and did you follow those 2 recommendations?
indeed i did.
what about your home directory? is it owned by you as well?
what happens if you delete the file and restart X11?
is that really a wise move?
there's nothing important in the file, it can be deleted without issue
yeah, my home folder is owned by me as well, by the way.
if you insist, move it out of the way and restart X
deleted and am restarting X.  brb
still says that it's being ignored.
i replaced it now, but the problem persisted when i deleted it.
right, i'm informing jrib of that so he doesn't waste time walking you through something that was already suggested. trying to save everyone a bit of time

i found a thread about it on the forums, and i'm trying to change the permissions on my home folder with sudo chmod -R 700, and it's saying that permission is denied to the .gvfs directory in my home.
.gvfs contains mounts to other locations, you've likely made a smb/nfs/ssh connection to a remote filesystem
700 is also almost certainly not the permissions you want, as you'll likely run into problems with permissions that are that strict
you certainly don't have to reinstall

you can use find to identify files in your home directory, and do exclusions with that. omit the -R flag from chmod and chown in this case.  see the manpage for find for exact syntax of how to ignore certain files and directories
like i said, you'll have to read the manpage, i don't have the linux syntax for it memorized, and I think it's different in BSD (the only manpage for it i have access to right now)

if you don't have anything important in your home directory, you can just delete your user and create a new one (and if you do have things that are important, just back them up and/or copy them to the new users directory)
it's a reasonable option if you feel like you messed up permissions that badly
i think i did.  it's not even letting me open my home folder in the file browser.
in fact, it's not letting me do anything.
it will not let me use my menues to add a user because it can't access my home folder.  how can i add a user through bash?
adduser

you'll want to make sure he's a member of the admin group as well, otherwise you won't be able to sudo (make sure this works before you delete your current user, otherwise you will lose root access to the machine, and I really don't want to walk you through how to fix that)
right.  i'm not familiar with adding users to groups, could you help me with that?
groupadd i think?
don't do what dulak says, you don't want to set your default group to admin, you want your default group to be your username
no
i did it after i created the user.
then you are probably ok.
sudo su yournewuser and then touch a file, and ls -l the file, see if it looks right
you'll probably want to cd to /tmp first
and then sudo touch a file, and make sure sudo works
when i tried to "sudo su nick2", it said 'To run a command as administrator (user "root"), use sudo <command>, See "man sudo_root" for details.
hrmm, that's new.  unsure
use exit
it will fail, unless you are user nick already
/ bazhang: what happens if i chown -R nick /home/nick while su?
why will it fail?  i thought root had absolute priveleges.
you su'd to nick2, not root
i'm root at the moment.
by accident, really, but i'm still root.
it will have the same effect as sudoing (you will fail at .gvfs)
any way to change back to nick instead of root without using exit?  exit will close the terminal, and i don't have menu permissions to reopen it.
exit will not close the terminal
oh, right.
a terminal will close when the process that is running in it (your original bash), exits.  you aren't closing the original bash, so the terminal will not close
i'm trying to recover some stuff from my root folder, but nick2 doesn't have permissions to enter it.  is there any way to get into the folder?
it doesn't like sudo cd.
which root folder?  /root?
mistyped.  meant home.
by default it is, most *nix distributions will have an actual executable file in /bin though as well
you can use the one in /bin by specifying /bin/cp instead of just cp
would i use the -r option to move whole directories.  oh, and if i copy stuff over, won't it still have the same permissions as before?
depending on what options you specify for copy, it might.  read the manpage for cp to get a list of options
i know that i can switch between displays with ctrl-alt-fbuttons.  are any of those other gnome sessions, or is it only terminals?
ubuntu only starts 1 x session in it's default installation.  starting a second x server is non trivial
okay, just thought i would ask.
what's the bash command for displaying permissions?
stat will do it, so will ls -l
whenever i try to access /home/nick2 as nick2, it says permission denied. O.o;
ls -ld /home/nick2
drw-rw-r-- 3 nick2 nick2 4096 2008-11-13 20:52 /home/nick2
then you aren't accessing it as nick2, you are likely nick
you need execute permission on that
chmod +x /home/nick2
that worked, but what did it do?  what does execute permission mean?
to cd to a directory, it needs execute permissions
could that be my problem for my main user?
it could.
you really should stop playing with permissions until you know what they do
i was just following instructions that were in the beginners section of the forums.  it worked for like, 20 people, and i thought i had a pretty good grasp of what they did, but apparently not.
i know you said to stop fooling with permissions, but i think that i have this solved, i just need to make sure that what i'm about to do isn't a terrible idea.

i got access to all of my stuff again by accessing a different drive in file browser, navigating to home, right clicking and choosing properties.  under permissions, i gave user:nick file read and write priveleges.  all of my stuff seems to be working at first glance.  question: should i hit the button that says to apply this to all internal files?
sure
where is the sudoers file, just so i can look in it and make sure that my other account is in it in case not everything is fixed?
it's not going to be in the sudoers file
log in as the user and type "id" and make sure that under groups you are in admin.  better yet, just try to sudo a command while you are the new user
finally, what's the command for deleting a user?  apparently not rmuser.
i'm guessing.. deluser
second guess would be userdel
you
you've been amazingly helpful, and i've noticed that you're constantly helping other people as well.  thank you tons.
i'm just answering basics. I don't know much :(
regardless, you're devoting quite a bit of time just to helping others.  it's awesome.
as a final check, what should my permissions on my home folder be before i don't touch them again?  664 or 667?

i think it should be 664, since there doesn't seem to be any logic allowing others more access than myself.  on the other hand, i thought that what i was doing last time was right as well, so i figured i'd ask.
my home dir is 755
alright, so i'll set it to that.
